qa.question: What do you mainly use your phone for?
qa.answer: I use it to chat with friends on WhatsApp and Snapchat, watch reels on Instagram, and sometimes attend online classes.

qa.question: Do you share your phone with others?
qa.answer: No. It’s my personal phone. But my younger brother sometimes takes it to play games.

qa.question: What are your favorite apps or features on your phone?
qa.answer: Snapchat, WhatsApp, Instagram. I don’t really think about data. I just click ‘Allow’. My friends do the same.

qa.question: When an app asks for permission, like access to location or contacts, do you read and understand what it means?
qa.answer: No. I skip all that to use the app quickly.

qa.question: How do you decide whether an app or website is safe to use?
qa.answer: If my friends use it or if it’s popular on the Play Store, I trust it.

qa.question: Have you ever deleted a message, photo, or app because you didn’t want someone to see it?
qa.answer: Yes, especially when I have chats I don’t want my brother to see. I also delete screenshots and messages from Snapchat.

qa.question: If your phone stops working and you need to give it for repair, what do you do before handing it over?
qa.answer: I give it to a nearby repair shop. I try to delete chats first, but if the screen is broken, I just give it as is.

qa.question: Have you ever asked someone to help you with a phone problem?
qa.answer: Yes, I ask my cousin. I feel awkward if he sees my photos, so I hide the gallery app.

qa.question: Who do you trust most when sharing personal or sensitive information?
qa.answer: Only my best friend. I avoid sharing sensitive stuff on group chats.

qa.question: Have you used code words or nicknames to keep something private?
qa.answer: Yes! On Snapchat, we use emojis and short names to hide meaning from others.

qa.question: Have you ever helped someone install or use an app?
qa.answer: Yes, I helped my aunt install a health app and showed her how to make payments on PhonePe.

qa.question: Do you know how to stop an app from using your camera or location?
qa.answer: I just found out my friend showed me how to go to settings.

qa.question: When you get a warning message (‘this app may harm your phone’), what do you usually do?
qa.answer: If I really need it, I install it anyway. Otherwise, I ignore it.

qa.question: What do you think happens when you give an app access to your contacts or photos?
qa.answer: I think it just helps me share things faster. I didn’t know they keep it or stored it elsewhere.

qa.question: Have you ever hesitated to take your phone for repair because of private content?
qa.answer: Yes. I felt embarrassed about the chats and photos, but I needed to fix it.

qa.question: Has a repair person ever opened your gallery or apps without asking?
qa.answer: Yes, my cousin once. I got angry and added a fingerprint lock.

qa.question: Do you use a password or lock screen on your phone? Why or why not?
qa.answer: Yes, fingerprint and pattern both. I don’t want anyone checking my phone.

qa.question: Do you think local apps are safer than international ones? Why?
qa.answer: I don’t know. I just use what’s trending.

qa.question: Who do you turn to when you don’t understand a phone or app setting?
qa.answer: My cousin sometimes searches YouTube.

qa.question: Do people around you influence how you think about online safety?
qa.answer: Yes, my friends tell me not to use random links. We talk about scams sometimes.

scenarios.Broken Phone: I try to delete chats and pictures first. If the phone is dead, I feel scared they’ll check everything.
scenarios.Sharing a Phone with Family: If my brother borrows it, I close all chats and hide Snapchat. I don’t want him teasing me.
scenarios.Installing a New App: If it looks fun, I install it. I click ‘Allow’ without checking. Later, I will remove it if it bothers me.
scenarios.Helping an Elderly Relative: I installed a government pension app for my grandmother. I didn’t explain much — just said ‘click here.’
scenarios.Using a Borrowed Phone: If I see a personal photo, I pretend I didn’t. Privacy is important.
scenarios.Selling or Giving Away a Phone: Before giving my old phone to my cousin, I deleted apps, but didn’t know how to reset it fully.
scenarios.Cloud Backup Surprise: Yes! I deleted something, and it still showed up in Google Photos. I was shocked.
scenarios.Using Free Public WiFi: Yes, I connect to the cafe WiFi to watch videos. But I don’t use it for payments or bank stuff.
scenarios.Receiving a lottery: I got a message once. I blocked the number immediately. Looked fake.
scenarios.Sharing account details: If my best friend needs help, I’ll send her money using PhonePe. But I’ll double-check it’s really her.
